name: naproanilide
Reason: Naproanilide has a melting point that can be predicted by analyzing its structural components. The basic unit is naphthalene, which has a melting point of around 95 degrees Celsius. The introduction of an aniline group increases the melting point due to the potential for hydrogen bonding and dipole-dipole interactions, estimated at around +20 degrees Celsius. The ketone group introduces polar carbonyl interactions, raising the melting point by approximately +30 degrees Celsius. The methoxy group introduces a hydrogen bonding potential, estimated at around +10 degrees Celsius. The ethoxy group introduces a hydrogen bonding potential, estimated at around +10 degrees Celsius. The naphthalene base has a melting point of around 95 degrees Celsius. The aniline group, ketone group, methoxy group, and ethoxy group contribute to the melting point as follows: naphthalene base (95 degrees Celsius), aniline group (20 degrees Celsius), ketone group (30 degrees Celsius), methoxy group (10 degrees Celsius), and ethoxy group (10 degrees Celsius).
